Description: Bronze axe-head: with thick elongated lugs. It has been completely cleaned of corrosion product. Hammer marks are visible, especially on the sides. The cutting edge is quite sharp and its corners are cusped. It is slightly damaged. There are a large number of scratches and small cracks all over the blade. Chased on one face is a hieroglyphic inscriptio, possibly to be understood as meaning 'number seven'. The figure of the bird is not as deeply chased as the numerals.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: James, 'British Museum Quarterly' 24 (London, 1961), 39; E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 112, G- X/12, pl. XV, 2.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (132)
